content:
‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Completed in Python, checked with C conversion also (Needed to use 0xA7 for ¬ß).
Good implementation of RLE.

Could benefit from one more test/validator that is more random and less symmetrical (in terms of the ship itself).

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: A good puzzle, I like it.
Good description and cases. 
Several unexpexted hurdles keep you thinking.

I like the idea, but if it is rotated by 180¬∞, shouldn't the ^ become a v ?
I would love to have a validator + test case which is a text. (Picked up the newspaper instead of the blueprint), where the majority of the stuff is junk (not just the ~7 junk character what is used now).

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: for me it's a good puzzle
I'm not sure if I enjoy the "Remember that rotating 180¬∞ would be flipping and reversing, not just flipping." hint ¬Ø\_(„ÉÑ)_/¬Ø

can you add a case where the drone is not symmetric?, it would be nice to check if people do good the rotation of 180¬∞.

i think something like this must work
input:
6
3
1
.^^^^.
+^^^^+
+#¬ß@#+

output: 

1 Fuel, 1 Block, 1 Gyroscope, 1 Core, 1 Block, 2 Fuels, 4 Thrusters, 1 Fuel, 4 Thrusters

Goal
* Please change "a ASCII" to "an ASCII".

* Please change "0 or 180¬∞" to "0¬∞ or 180¬∞".

* Please add "(any characters other than {{#}}, {{^}}, {{@}}, {{+}} and {{¬ß}}, including newlines and space characters)" after "junk tiles".

* Please add "and should not interrupt the encoding" after "ignored".

* Please change "renamed to" to "replaced by".

* Please change "it's" to "its".

Tags
* Suggest to add "Run-length encoding".

Input
* Line 3:
  ‚Ä¢ Please change "A" to "An".
  
  ‚Ä¢ Please change "0 and 180 rotation" to "no rotation and 180¬∞ rotation respectively".

Output / Cases
* Please mention that name means the tile's name and amount means the number of consecutive occurrences of that tile.

* Please delete "Newlines, empty space, or junk characters should not interrupt the encoding".

* Please revise the output format so that it is not specific to any programming languages (currently you just print `rows` without the need to do any formatting).

* Some cases have redundant newlines at the end (Test 1 "Drone Boi" and Test 4 "Upside Down"). Please remove all of them.

* Each pair of test and validator should be similar, and ordered from simple to complex. Please swap around the cases and revise them where necessary. For example,

Test 1: Simple drone with no rotation and no junk tiles
Validator 1: Similar to but different from Test 1

Test 2: Simple drone with 180¬∞ rotation and no junk tiles
Validator 2: Similar to but different from Test 2

Test 3: Simple drone with no rotation and junk tiles
Validator 3: Similar to but different from Test 3

Test 4: Simple drone with 180¬∞ rotation and junk tiles
Validator 4: Similar to but different from Test 4

Test 5: Single character with no rotation
Validator 5: Similar to but different from Test 5

Test 6: Single character with 180¬∞ rotation
Validator 6: Similar to but different from Test 6

Test 7: Complex drone with no rotation and junk tiles
Validator 7: Similar to but different from Test 7

Test 8: Complex drone with 180¬∞ rotation and junk tiles
Validator 8: Similar to but different from Test 8

By "complex" I mean (a) larger grids and (b) at least the same type of tiles appears more than once and separated by other types of tiles, e.g. ['Block', 4], ['Fuel', 2], ['Block', 4].

You're not limited to 8 pairs of cases. You can add even more as appropriate.

* Please also ensure that the different types of tiles are covered adequately in all tests and in all validators similarly.

Thanks.

Thanks for the help! Adding the new test cases might take me a few hours as my ipad doesn't let me copy or paste to and from most interpreter consoles, meaning I'll have to manually write the outputs.
Done, made 'Cluttered' asymmetric.
For the rotation - I took it meaning that even if you did rotate ^ to be v, it would still be a 'Thruster' just looking at it from a different angle.

You wrote: "(Needed to use 0xA7 for ¬ß)."

Maybe you should not have approved it after you found out that the puzzle is not conforming its own statement... (that talks about ascii characters and not Unicode UTF-8...)

Agreed.

Having to correctly handle multi-byte unicode characters is definitely NOT a task that should be required of an 'easy' multi-language solo challenge... even if the word ASCII is dropped from the statement.

The '¬ß' should have been changed to an ASCII character, before accepting : /

Not sure what can be done about it now that we're here : (

Let's be more careful people.

your  'Cluttered' asymmetric is good.... but you miss the R=1 for the 180¬∞ rotation :)

180¬∞ rotation  would be flipping and reversing, but only reversing is enough because the symmetry of your test.... in the line 27 of your code:
rows = [rows[n-1][::-1] for n in range(len(rows),0,-1)]

you pass all cases if you only do:
rows = [rows[n-1] for n in range(len(rows),0,-1)]

that's because all your test cases WITH rotation are symmetric.
Thanks, made validator 4 asymmetric.

Thank you for following up. There are still a few things to change:

Output
* Please change "<<{Tile occurences} {Tile name}>>" to "[[Tile occurrences]] [[Tile name]]". Remember to correct the typo and text formatting at the same time.

* Please format "s" and "Nothing" as {{constants}} and remove the quotation marks.

* Please change "excluding empty space and junk characters" to "separated by a comma and a space".

Cases
* Please swap "Empty" (validator) with "What?" (test) so that "What?" becomes a validator and "Empty" becomes a test.

* "Big Boi" (test): Please change the input so that there are *consecutive* Cores and *consecutive* Gyroscopes.

* Validator 7: Please change the input so that there are *consecutive* Cores.

Thanks.
Done!

'¬ß' is ABSOLUTELY NOT an ASCII character...

... it's a multi-byte unicode character - and handling those really shouldn't be required in an 'easy' multi-language solo challenge.

Unfortunately, it's been approved - which, in my view, was a mistake : /

Let's be more careful people : (

I understand your perspective, but in my view, this isn‚Äôt a mistake. The description originally included "ASCII," but that has since been removed from the puzzle statement. Honestly, many human languages include accented or other Unicode characters, I don't think it's too harsh to treat handling non-ASCII characters as a basic requirement, even at the easy difficulty level. Of course, I respect that you may see it differently.
Even UK's currency symbol ¬£ and smart quotes (‚Äú /‚Äâ‚Äò / ‚Äô /‚Äâ‚Äù) are non-ASCII characters, if we consider the English language only.

Thanks for taking the time to respond.

Of course, '¬£' is still single-byte.  And I DO understand where you're coming from... but I believe I have some pretty strong arguments that may well change your mind.

Argument 1 :

The template code assumes single-bytes... and allocates space accordingly.

    for (int i = 0; i < Y; i++) {
        char ROW[X + 1];
        scanf("%[^\n]", ROW); fgetc(stdin);
    }

You'll note that the template code overflows the memory allocated for the string... and that should NEVER happen!  The template code (On an EASY puzzle particularly) should be expected to be valid and error free.

Worse.  This template will appear to work, but will corrupt other variables - leaving a newbie with absolutely no idea where their code is suddenly misbehaving.  It isn't ... it's the template corrupting the stack frame.

Subtle errors caused by memory corruption from the supplied code is, I'd argue, NOT something a newbie should be dealing with on an EASY puzzle.

Would you agree?

Argument 2 :

I have completed every 'easy', almost every 'medium' and a fair number of 'hard' and even a quarter of the "very hard" ... and this is the first time I've come across ANY unicode.  I can attest that it is the only EASY that throws unicode into the mix.

Now, that wouldn't be a problem if the task was specifically unicode related.  But, when it's not, then it's just a needless tripwire.

But I'm not against unicode.  I actually think a unicode-based puzzle would be a good thing... as it's a vital aspect of real-world coding.

Argument 3 :

There is no 'balancing' argument I can find, in favour of '¬ß' over 's'

If we consider the issues, including the invalidation of the template code... I think it's almost impossible to make a compelling case for '¬ß' as opposed to, say, 's' which would fulfill the same purpose - within the context of the puzzle and the specific skills it purports to test.

So, I'd argue that it's ALL downside... with no redeeming purpose.


Having said all that...

I do agree with you that unicode is something that every coder needs to understand... but I posit that it would be better to introduce unicode handling in a challenge where handling unicode is the stated task.

Throwing random unicode into a challenge that is not explicitly unicode focused, is just an unnecessary tripwire for new players.  Especially when it causes data corruption in the template code.

I'd argue that, on 'Easy', the supplied template should, at least be valid!


Personally, I find the above arguments pretty compelling.

... but have I convinced you?

If not, no worries.  We're all friends here and I'd still buy you a beer!  : )))))

Thank you for explaining your rationale.

Argument 1: I agree completely. I've changed Line 4 of the stub accordingly.

Argument 2: There may be more than you think; here are some easy puzzles with non-ASCII input:
https://www.codingame.com/training/easy/what-is-your-garden-worth
https://www.codingame.com/training/easy/benfords-law
https://www.codingame.com/training/easy/by-train-or-by-car
https://www.codingame.com/training/easy/six-degrees-of-kevin-bacon
https://www.codingame.com/training/easy/tabloid-couple-names
https://www.codingame.com/training/easy/the-alien-business-of-cows

There's even one easy puzzle requiring non-ASCII output:
https://www.codingame.com/training/easy/nature-of-triangles

Argument 3: I agree, but it's the author's design choice. Ultimately argument 3 won't hold if argument 1 doesn't hold.

I won't claim to be an expert in the area of non-ASCII characters, but I do have some experience with it. I was the one who asked CG to fix the console last year. Before the fix, the console didn't always display non-ASCII characters correctly, and I would be one of the reviwers to request authors of contributions to remove any such characters. As mentioned in my previous comment, I found it surprising that CG couldn't support such a fundamental feature properly.

Now that it's been fixed, it's a new chapter for CG. There still aren't many contributions featuring non-ASCII characters, so I appreciate you pointing out the issue with the code template. This helps me understand potential pitfalls better and improve future contributions accordingly. üòâ

Wow, I can't believe I'd forgotten about those contributions.  Thanks for the correction.  I've been here way too long and my brain is getting way too smooth.  I think I'll be getting put out to pasture soon ; )

I think we can draw a distinction between unicode input and unicode output.

Unicode output is something that a beginner can 'paste in' from the statement, since the UI permits it.  The fact that it is unicode won't necessarily be a problem.

printf("üçìü•íüåøüåπ");  // This output 'just works'(tm) ... even in crunchy old 'c'


But I think multi-byte input poses a significant challenge for the beginner.  You cannot getchar a 'üçì' ... and getting into properly setting locales and switching the template to wide characters is a hurdle for the beginner... moreso when the default template appears, at first glance, to work as intended.

Perhaps it would be nice if  'setlocale' and  'wchar_t' were a part of the template on such unicode input puzzles, as it gives a stronger (see: valid) place to start.

But, I'm certain that throwing a single non-graphical unicode character into an ostensibly ASCII-looking input, is perhaps just a little too opaque and is likely a recipe for frustration.

Personally I'd suggest :

1. Unicode output... great, it's pretty and it's fun!  Let's have more of that : )

2. Unicode input should serve a purpose and it's use should be obvious and explicitly mentioned in the problem statement.

3. The automatic template generation should perhaps be more robust, and detect when when the supplied tests and validators contain multi-byte characters on the input - so that the templates themselves don't become a trip hazard.

But I yield to your experience.

Thanks for the correction, and for entertaining my little geriatric tirade in good humour ; )

Have a wonderful day o/

Haha, I love the ‚Äògeriatric tirade‚Äô. I definitely appreciate the perspective, and I've learned a thing or two! More brains = more ideas, and that‚Äôs always a good thing - we need more!

Getting CG to update the template is a tough ask (many good recommendations haven‚Äôt been acted upon yet‚Ä¶), but I‚Äôll keep your good suggestions in mind when reviewing contributions.

Thanks for the great input, and have an awesome day! o/

This is not a key feature of the puzzle, but just a poor choice of symbol that should have been corrected at the moderation stage, and not left as is. The fact that instead of that symbol, for example, the dollar sign $ is used, the puzzle task will not change, but it will improve the impression of the puzzle, and get rid of dissatisfied comments.

I'd abandoned this account for a while by the time this comment came in, so i didn't get to see it - multi-byte characters were something i hadn't considered at all when designing this, as i normally use python, which doesn't run into memory management issues like that. I've modified the testcases to use "$" instead of "¬ß", which should hopefully fix that issue.
Don't forget to modify the Goal section too!
is it a good idea to break existing solutions?
It isn't, and it's difficult to balance different aspects.
Modified goals, thanks
It's not a good idea, but it's a 2-minute fix for people who've already solved it, rather than potential hours of difficulties for people just now attempting to solve
Thank you.
